name: Advanced nodes - Translating node
description: This tutorial will help you learn how to solve kinematics problems with translating and clamped translating nodes.

pages.textBefore: Translating nodes are typically going to be defined using a linear function y = mx + b and the distance along the line from the origin.
pages.textAfter: In this example, the slope is 1, the y-intercept is 0 and the distance along the line is 1. In order to get the coordinates of the point, imagine that the line is the hypotenuse of a right triangle. The angle of a line is equal to the inverse tangent of the slope so the coordiantes are (l*cos(tan⁻¹(m)), l*sin(tan⁻¹(m)) + b) where l is the distance along the line, m is the slope and b is the y-intercept. Using the values given in the example, the point is at (1*cos(tan⁻¹(1)), 1*sin(tan⁻¹(1)) + 0) = (cos45°, sin45°) = (√2/2, √2/2)
